intro: Rytidolobus appendiculatus, commonly known as the narrow-leafed sedge, is a flowering plant native to parts of Southeast Asia. It belongs to the family Cyperaceae, which includes sedges, and is characterized by its grass-like appearance with triangular stems. The plant typically grows in wetland or marshy environments, thriving in moist, nutrient-rich soils. Its small, inconspicuous flowers are clustered in dense spikes, and it plays a role in stabilizing wetland ecosystems. Rytidolobus appendiculatus is often used in ecological restoration projects due to its ability to tolerate waterlogged conditions.
